Award.AwardTitle: Zinc Fingers as Templates for Metal Complex Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
DNA is recognized with exquisite specificity by a group of proteins collectively known as zinc fingers. The DNA-zinc finger interaction has important biological consequences, for example when cells divide or viruses multiply. The proposed experiments will explore a newly discovered means for disrupting the interaction using metal containing compounds (specifically platinum) discovered in the laboratory of the principal investigator. Future research will be conducted to understand and control this property for the development of new medicines like anti-viral (especially HIV) compounds. The approach will be both experimental (chemical and biological) and theoretical (computational). The project represents an excellent example of the linkage between basic research and discovery on one hand, and important societal benefits on the other. The research project will also be part of an international collaboration exposing graduate students to the subject, and to cross-cultural experiences.

With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Nicholas Farrell from Virginia Commonwealth University to characterize reactions of zinc finger proteins by the systematic study of steric and electronic effects of functionalized coordination compounds on the kinetics and thermodynamics of zinc displacement and disruption of protein structure and function. A specific focus will be on the HIV NCp7 nucleocapsid protein (NC), and the mechanism of platinum-metal nucleobases as nucleocapsid-nucleic acid antagonists through interruption of the NC-RNA(DNA) interaction will be examined. The factors affecting selective "non-covalent" ligand-biomolecule recognition through enhanced pi-pi; stacking between metallated nucleobases and the tryptophan-containing nucleocapsid will be examined. Secondly, such recognition can lead to formation of the "covalent" metal-thiolate bond and subsequent zinc ejection. We will explore the analogy of weak "organic" and "inorganic" electrophiles to design specific interactions differentiating the distinct Cys2His2, Cys3His and Cys4 zinc finger-binding sites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This bioinorganic chemistry project studied the interplay between the chemistry of inorganic compounds and biological life processes. Bioinorganic chemistry in its broadest definition is the study of the role of the metal in metalloproteins in health and disease as well as the use of small inorganic molecules in medicine. the specific metalloproteins studied were zinc fingers (ZFs) , a class of structural zinc proteins which account for 1-3% of the human genome. ZFs are nucleic acid binding proteins that exercise many important biological functions such as DNA repair and transcription and are increasingly recognized for their relevance in disease states such as inflamamtion, viral diseases and cancer. There is now a  total of 14 classes of ZFs known, differetniated to soeme xtent by the number of cysteine and histidine residues bound to zinc and their specific structures. A major question therefore is how does nature design apparently very similar structures to carry out individual tasks such as binding to specific nucleic acids and sequences ? To unravel ZF reactivity and contribute to understanding of the structure-activity relationships within ZFs we have applied theoretical and biophysical methods to the question of the nature of the zinc coordination sphere in metalloproteins, their function and the basis of their interaction with small platinum-metal (platinum, gold) compounds and the structures of the products. Coordination chemistry allows the study of steric and electronic effects of functionalized compounds in a systematic manner. The highly interdisciplinary initernational project integrated experimental (chemical and biological) techniques and spectroscopy as well as computational and bioinformatic approaches to examine these questions.

We studied principally the Sp1 transcription factor which is representative of the class of DNA-binding ZFs and the HIVNCp7 nucleocapsid protein which has a principal role in RNA binding and viral encapsidation. Nucleocapsid proteins in general are highly conserved among retroviruses and we examined how the cysteine content and their inherent reactivity affected ZF function. The role of ancillary ligands in the proteins was also examined. The key outcomes are that small molecules can be designed and synthesized to mimic the natural binding of nucleic acids to ZFs through molecular recognition and that formation of metal-sulfur bonds (from the proteins' cysteine groups) disrupts the three-dimensional  structure in a manner which is dependent on the exact nature of the ZF. Thus we provide proof-of-principle that new chemotypes are indeed capable of interrupting protein-DNA(RNA) interactions and have successfully confirmed the intellectual merit of the proposed activity in expanding the known properties of this important class of proteins in hitherto unrecognized directions. We have thus provided the scientific groundwork for the long-term possibilities of new medicinal applications, expanding frontiers and suggesting new mechanisms of action and targets for biologically active inorganic compounds to complement concepts from organic chemistry.

Science, and research in science, is more than ever a global enterprise. The benefits of international research are very clear and well documented, especially with increasing of information transfer. This project benefited by collaboration with Brazilian researchers through the "Science Without Borders" program. Brazilian undergraduate and postgraduate students visited our laboratories through exchange programs funded by their government to conduct research.  The Principal Investigator also exercised activities in Brazil as a Special Visiting Researcher and gave courses and organized research activities including small conferences of Brazilian and US (working at Virginia Commonwealth University, VCU) faculty to further catalyze and strengthen collaborations. Further international collaborations were with China where ongoing efforts include development of joint dual-degree programs between VCU and Chinese institutions. All students participating in these activities presented papers at scientific meetings as well as contributing to published articles in scientific journals, resulting in broad dissemination of the results. Fostering the development of bioinorganic chemistry worldwide is important and helping awareness of work being done in less recognized international arenas  can contribute to the success of meetings such as The International Conference on Bioinorganic Chemistry held recently in Brazil. The widespread dissemination of these activities may also contribute to expanding the balance of active researchers in chemistry in this country. Underrepresented groups participated in this research program. 

The long-term impact of this work for society is to expand the knowledge base; to challenge in a rational and innovative manner current concepts and to lay the groundwork for development of new medicines. The potential application of these basic results demonstrates the linkage between discovery and societal benefit by expanding the knowledge gained in diverse scientific areas  and placing both in new contexts and understanding.
